title: Venezuela frees a batch of political prisoners amid US threats
description: Venezuela released a group of political prisoners as President Donald Trump's administration ratchet...
content:
Venezuela released a group of political prisoners as President Donald Trump's administration ratchets up pressure on Nicolás Maduro's socialist regime.

Eight detainees were freed in the South American nation early Sunday, while five others will serve out the remainder of their sentences under house arrest, former governor and presidential candidate Henrique Capriles said in a post on X.

Among those released was Américo De Grazia, an ally of María Corina Machado, the banned opposition leader who represents the biggest challenge yet to Maduro's 12-year rule. Pedro Guanipa, the brother of a prominent jailed opposition figure, was given house arrest.

There were 815 political prisoners behind bars in Venezuela as of Aug. 21, according to Caracas-based human-rights group Foro Penal.

The U.S. recently deployed three warships, carrying 4,000 sailors and Marines, to the southern Caribbean as part of its efforts to combat drug cartels in the region. Earlier this month, Trump's attorney general doubled the bounty on Maduro's head to $50 million.

Trump's administration has also withheld approval for several oil majors seeking to resume operations in Venezuela, including Spain's Repsol SA, Italy's Eni SpA and Maurel & Prom of France, despite handing out a license last month for Chevron Corp. to resume pumping crude in the South American nation.

The U.S. State Department and Venezuela's information ministry didn't immediately reply to requests for comment on Sunday's prisoner release.

Last month, Maduro agreed to swap 10 American detainees and dozens of Venezuelan political prisoners in exchange for 250 Venezuelan migrants who had been deported to and locked up in El Salvador. It's unclear whether this latest batch was negotiated with the U.S. or meant to interfere with Trump's administration plans.

On Friday, Maduro invoked a former Venezuelan president, Cipriano Castro, who offered to open all doors for political prisoners amid tensions with the U.S. during his time in office in the early 1900s.

In remarks a day earlier, Maduro dismissed news of the U.S. deployment but nonetheless called on Venezuelans to unite and enlist. "We call to arms all militia members, to tell the imperialists: Enough of your threats, Venezuela rejects you!"

This story was originally published August 24, 2025 at 10:42 PM.
summary: Venezuela has released eight political prisoners, including Américo De Grazia, an ally of María Corina Machado, and Pedro Guanipa, who will serve out their sentences under house arrest. This move comes amid threats from the United States from President Donald Trump's administration, which has doubled the bounty on Maduro's head to $50 million. The U.S. has also withheld approval for several oil majors seeking to resume operations in Venezuela, despite giving out a license for Chevron to resume pumping crude there. It is unclear whether this latest batch of political prisoners was negotiated with the U.
shortSummary: Venezuela released eight political prisoners amid escalating US pressure, including a $50 million bounty on Maduro's head.
argos_summary: Venezuela freed eight political prisoners and placed five others under house arrest amid growing U.S. pressure, including a deployment of warships and a $50 million bounty on Maduro. The releases, announced by former governor Henrique Capriles, come as the U.S. has also tightened oil sanctions, withholding approvals for several European majors while granting a license to Chevron. Maduro has previously negotiated a prisoner swap for Venezuelan migrants and dismissed U.S. actions, calling for national unity against perceived imperialist threats.
